nodes.bodyText: Please revert this change. Since we don't know the final URL yet, your editor will add this once the article is published.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -13,3 +13,4 @@ The "REST With Spring" Classes: http://bit.ly/restwithspring
 - [Spring RequestMapping](https://www.baeldung.com/spring-requestmapping)
 - [Guide to DeferredResult in Spring](https://www.baeldung.com/spring-deferred-result)
 - [Using JSON Patch in Spring REST APIs](https://www.baeldung.com/spring-rest-json-patch)
+- [OpenAPI JSON Objects in Query Params](https://www.baeldung.com/openapi-json-objects-in-query-params)

nodes.bodyText: Two things starting with this line: First, the indentation is off. This path and the paths below should be indented the same as /tickets above. Second, why do we start putting everything in double quotes at this point? Although it is allowed, convention is to not use any quotes in an OpenAPI definition except where necessary.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,154 @@
+swagger: '2.0'
+...
+paths:
+  /tickets:
+    get:
+      parameters:
+        - in: query
+          name: params
+          required: true
+          description: A JSON object with the `type` and `color` properties
+          type: string
+          example: '{"type":"foo","color":"green"}'
+
+swagger: '2.0'
+...
+paths:
+  /tickets:
+    post:
+      requestBody:
+          description: Parameter is an object that should be serialized as JSON
+          content:
+            application/json:
+              schema:
+              	type: string
+          		example: '{"type":"foo","color":"green"}'
+      responses:
+        '200':
+          description: successful process
+
+"/api/tickets": {

nodes.bodyText: Are we putting the ... here and other places below as a shorthand notation to say that in a real OpenAPI definition, there would be more here? That's fine for snippets in the article, but the code in the repository should reflect complete and syntactically correct examples. In fact, the article has 2.0 and 3.0 examples, so we should have one file here for the 2.0 definition and one for the 3.0 definition. Both should be complete definitions.
